DESMOND, Forrest E., 606-47-01, MOMMlc, V-6, USNR,
throttleman in Forward Engine Room, while securing
No. 1 engine from charge inadvertantly closed the out-
board exhasut valve on No. 2 engine which was running
at the time. The engine continued running, lifting
the relief valves and filling the room with exhaust
gases. After Engine Room crew seoing the smoke,
passed word "Fire" and secured the bulkhead between
engine rooms. DESMOND attempted to secure the engine
but was overcome by the fumes. Engines were secured
from Maneuvering Room. REMILL RD, Earl D., 212-52-91,
CMOMM(A) (T), USN entered the compartment without
smoke mask and secured the ventilation. He too was
overcome but was immediately removed by KUTZLEB
Robert E., 224-26-28, MOMMlc, USN who had covered
his face with a wet rag before entering. KUTZLEB
returned to the Control Room and, hearing that
DESMOND was unaccounted for grabbed an oxygen rescue
breathing apparatus and started aft adjusting the
apparatus as he went. The engaging hand wheel broke
off before the canister was pierced. The apparatus
furnished no protection but KUTZLEB, realizing that
time was precious continued on using the mask. He
crawled the length of the compartment to the throttle
station searching for DESMOND. Not finding him,
KUTZLEB closed the engine throttle and fought his way
back out of the compartment. DESMOND, meanwhile had
passed out against the after bulkhead. He was re-
moved into the After Engine Room. Commanding Officer &
Pharmacist's Mate had meanwhile gone up and over into
the After Torpedo Room and DESMOND was immediately
given artificial respiration and put on oxygen. I
have gone to some length on this account to emphasize
the toxic, blinding, and demoralizing effect of a
smoke filled compartment and the necessity for thorough

U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Fourth War Patrol,
The fourth war patrol of the U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) covered a period
of fifty-six (56) days of which twenty-five (25) were spent in areas off the
INDO-CHINA Coast. Although many sampans and sailboats were encountered, only a
few targets were considered worthy of torpedo fire. Two-way communication with
friendly search planes was unreliable and offered little opportunity to vector
COPIA to enemy surface contacts. U.S.S. COBIA (SS245), U.S.S. ROCK (SS274), and
U.S.S. GUAVIANA (SS362) formed a Coordinated Attack Group, the Commanding Officer
U.S.S. COPIA being Officer in Tactical Command during the period 19-26 March.
Upon joining Group on 27 March, the Commanding Officer U.S.S. ROCK assumed duties
of Officer in Tactical Commend. On 21 February a main engine was improperly
secured from a charge, resulting in a near casualty to personnel from fumes
emitted into a closed engine room. The heroic action of REMILLARD, Earl D.,
CMOME (AA) (T), USN, and KUTZLEB, Robert E., MoMMlc, USN, without rogard to
personal safety, demonstrated their courage and resourcefulness as submariners
and upheld the high traditions of the naval service. KUTZLEB'S actions un-
questionably saved the lives of both REMILLARD and DESMOND, Forrest E., MOMMlc,
V-6, USNR, the throttloman on the affected engine. The Commanding Officer's
decision to return to EXMOUTH for medical treatment for injured personnel is
considered sound in view of the short distance to run. The COBIA arrived
EXMOUTH GULF on 23 February, transferred DESMOND to U.S.S. COUCAL, and departod
the following day.
2.
On 26 February, two sea trucks, 300 tons each, were sighted through
the periscope, and proparations made to attack them with guns. They were engaged
soparately, and both sunk by the experienced gun crows of this submarine which
has accounted for six small craft by gun fire in four war patrols. Unfortunately,
return fire from the second target wounded two members of the 20mm gun crew, and
HUSTON, Ralph C., Jr., Slc, V-6, USNR, succumbed to gunshot wounds the following
day, when COBIA was returning to FREMANTLE at four engine specd to transfor
wounded personnel and effect repairs to a holod SJ radar wave guide and defective
lobing motor. She arrived FREMANTLE on 4 March, made necessary repairs, and
departed for patrol 8 March.
3.
On 14 February a snoko contact developed into a five ship convoy,
consisting of two small coastal freighters and two escorts. An approach was made
on one froightor which was subsequently attacked with four Mk 14-3A torpedoes,
four foot dopth setting. The Commanding Officer watched two torpedoes run under-

One floating mino was sighted off CMRANH BAY on 29 March; a

An attempt was made to communicato, both with SD most and VHF antennas, with

5.
The material condition of the CODIA on return from patrol is above
average and a normal refit will be conducted. The moralc, health and appearance
of the officers and crew does not show any ill effects from this long patrol,
and they are welcomed alongside their own Tonder for the COBIA's first refit by
Squadron Twenty-two forces. They are congratulated on the successful completion
of another war patrol, the damage inflicted on the onomy, and upon the excellent
manner in which seven Army fliers were rescued.
6.

the loss of HOUSTON, Ralph Clark, Jr., 755-96-96, Slc, V-6, USNR, by enemy action.

U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Fourth War
Patrol, Comment on.
The Fourth War Patrol of the COBIA, under the command
of Commander A. L. BECKER, U.S.N., was conducted in three phases as
outlined in the First Endorsement.
2.
The Commanding Officer's decision to return DESMOND,
F. E., MoMMlo, U.S.N.R., to EMOUTH for medical treatment, following
the unfortunate casualty in the forward engine room on 21 February,
was correct.
3.
The loss of HUSTON, R. C., Jr., Slc, U.S.N.R., as a
result of wounds sustained at 1822 en 26 February during a gun battle
with the enemy is deeply regretted. During this gun action the range
was closed to well inside the range of the enemy armament, and COBIA
received hits upon two occasions. The first series of hits occurred
at 1816, and caused a fire in the magazine of the 20MM gun. The
second series of enemy hits occurred at 1822 and resulted in HUSTON's
receiving a mortal wound and BROTCHIE, T. H., FC2c, U.S.N.R., receiv-
ing a superficial wound. Following these incidents COBIA opened to
a safe range and proceeded to deliberately and skilfully destroy the
enemy. Two sea trucks were sunk in this engagement.
4.
On 8 April seven downed aviators were rescued in the
CAPE PADARAN Area.
5.
The award of the Submarine Combat Insignia is author-
ized for this patrol.
6..
The Force Commander congratulates the Commanding
Officer, Officers and Crew of the COBIA upon their completion of a
long patrol and upon the rescue of seven aviators. The following
damage to the enemy is assessed:
